content:
I think you'll find that "Fleabag" explores some similar themes and motifs that you enjoyed in "Schitt's Creek", but in a slightly different way.

One of the main themes of "Fleabag" is family dynamics, particularly the complex and often fraught relationships between siblings, parents, and children. Fleabag's family is dysfunctional, to say the least, and the show explores the ways in which they navigate their relationships with each other. You'll see echoes of the Rose family's quirks and flaws in Fleabag's family, but with a darker and more cynical tone.

Identity is also a major theme in "Fleabag", although it's explored in a more introspective and personal way. Fleabag's struggles with her own identity, her relationships, and her place in the world are all deeply relatable, and you'll likely find yourself nodding along with her observations and insights.

Another theme that's present in both "Schitt's Creek" and "Fleabag" is the idea of finding one's true self and living authentically. Fleabag's journey is all about figuring out who she is, what she wants, and how to live a life that's true to herself, despite the challenges and obstacles that come her way.

You'll also notice that both shows feature complex, flawed, and often unlikeable characters, which adds to their relatability and humanity. Fleabag is a deeply flawed and often selfish character, but she's also vulnerable, relatable, and ultimately, very human.

Finally, both shows use humor to tackle darker topics and themes, although "Fleabag" is certainly more cynical and irreverent in its approach. You'll find that the show's humor is often uncomfortable, awkward, and even cringe-worthy at times, but it's also laugh-out-loud funny and deeply relatable.

Overall, I think you'll find that "Fleabag" explores many of the same themes and motifs that you enjoyed in "Schitt's Creek", but with a darker, more cynical, and more introspective tone.
